Test capacity utilization rate (Pillar 2): 84.8% Testing capacity utilization as of 11 June 2020 is on high levels, while positive tests remain relatively moderate. Thus, the daily positivity rate fell to less than 0.9% in both pillars. Two conclusions make me shift my forecast more towards the crowd temporarily:
1) I probably overestimated the need to further expand testing capacity, as current capacity utilization indicates that testing has never been stretched or fully used in the past 10 days or so. It is just speculation to contemplate about the rationale behind it (Are tests too costly? Do people have to have symptoms to be eligible for testing? Who pays for tests, and who decides on the admission to tests? Will the world be short of test kits soon, as densely populated nations (India, Pakistan, Brasil and others) absorb an ever growing share of testing material; is the NHS therefore setting aside test kits for the medium term/possible second wave?) 2) Positivity rate is volatile, but seems to decline overall. UK is currently far from my worst case-scenario in daily confirmed cases. A rise to 2,000 cases or more a day is likely in the wake of the government ending some of the lockdown measures soon. But effects will probably not fade in before 20 June 2020 and thus might not suffice for the number of cumulative cases as of 30 June 2020 to cross the next threshold. As soon as new clusters arise or London and other crowded places will be more affected, the tides may turn and I will return to the 340k-420k range.

I still consider it more likely than not that cases by end June are lower than 340,000 - for cases to be higher than this the new cases each day would need to increase from their current level which I currently consider unlikely, particularly looking at the experience of other countries where the downward trend in cases has not reversed.  However, despite this I'm updating my forecast to place marginally more wait on a >340k level for two reasons: 1.) the daily cases figure has been stubbornly around 1500 whereas I had previously forecast it would have fallen to comfortably below 1k by now; 2.) the BLM protests and easing of lockdown restrictions raise the likelihood that R could go above 1 meaning growth in number of daily cases

As we'll see this is not completely accurate... https://coronavirus.data.gov.uk/ The numbers for testing are harder to find and evaluate, since England + Wales is reported separately from Scotland and Northern Ireland/other territories.  https://www.gov.uk/guidance/coronavirus-covid-19-information-for-the-public
see 'Time series' First of all, the "Sit Rep" Situation Report of the WHO will be published with data " received by WHO from national authorities by 10:00 CEST" on a regular basis which will be Sit Rep No. 162 published on 30 June 2020 10:00 CEST in our case . Since the UK report their figures on a daily basis at 5:00 pm GMT/UTC +1 (~ British Summer Time (BST) or 6:00 pm CEST), the data as of 30 June 2020 presumably will be included in this resolution, if WHO means "10:00 pm CEST". It has not been mentioned explicitly, so it's a little confusing to me, but I will watch that. Thus, the time span for cases under investigation will end on 30 June 2020 from my perspective. Then, the "date of activity" lags behind the "date of report" in the UK figures for one day, which should not matter under normal circumstances, as long as reports flow in consistently and continuously. In the UK testing methodology, it is distinguished between four different Pillars, "Pillar 1" to "Pillar 4",  "Breakdown of testing by testing strategy ‘pillars’     Pillar 1: swab testing in Public Health England (PHE) labs and NHS hospitals for those with a clinical need, and health and care workers
    Pillar 2: swab testing for the wider population, as set out in government guidance
    Pillar 3: serology testing to show if people have antibodies from having had COVID-19
    Pillar 4: serology and swab testing for national surveillance supported by PHE, ONS, Biobank, universities and other partners to learn more about the prevalence and spread of the virus and for other testing research purposes, for example on the accuracy and ease of use of home testing" of which Pillar 1 and Pillar 2 seem to be the most fundamental and have the most capacity, and numbers of Pillar 3 & 4 do not flow in to the cumulative number of confirmed cases: "Testing capacity as of 2 June  At 9am on 2 June (as reported on 3 June 2020), testing capacity was 220,213  Pillar 1       Pillar 2        Pillar 3      Pillar 4          Total
 63,213       116,000       40,000      1,000            220,213       Lab capacity However, the total number of "tested people" (1,267,099) (corrected for double tested persons and in contrast to the cumulative number of tests (1,770,451)) is only available for pillar 1, which means a discount with a 39.7 per cent of excess testing per person. The Pillar 2 tests (116,000 capacity per day on 2 June 2020) have almost twice the capacity of Pillar 1 (63,213 per day), but have faded in to its full extent at a later stage of the national testing strategy at the end of April, e.g.: 23.04.2020 UK Pillar 1 (plus Pillar 2 for Wales)    20088
23.04.2020 UK Pillar 2 (excluding Wales)     2985 26.04.2020 UK Pillar 1 (plus Pillar 2 for Wales  17939
26.04.2020 UK Pillar 2 (excluding Wales)   11119 29.04.2020 UK Pillar 1 (plus Pillar 2 for Wales)     23648
29.04.2020 UK Pillar 2 (excluding Wales)    28539 02.05.2020 UK Pillar 1 (plus Pillar 2 for Wales)   39095
02.05.2020 UK Pillar 2 (excluding Wales)    64894 That is why Pillar 1 tests only account for 37% (1,770,451 tests out of 4,786,219) of all cumulative tests so far, but for about 67,1% (187,823 confirmed cases out of 279,856)  of all confirmed cases so far. Pillar 2 accounts for about 54% (2,582,681 out of 4,786,219 tests), but "only" 32,9% (92,033 out of 279,856) cases reported so far. Of course, Pillar 1-tests are more likely to confirm new cases, as they are taken from persons with health issues (or symptoms) and people on the front line. It is also likely that the testing strategy contains testing more and more asymptomatic persons in the wake of contact tracing (which contains a lot of negative persons) after Pillar 2 has increased to higher capacity, or this suggests that "testing effectiveness" is somehow less with Pillar 2-tests than with Pillar 1-tests. Having said this, one can assert that the number of daily Pillar 1 tests for UK as a whole (including Pillar 2 for Wales) has on average hovered around 27k and 35k (rough estimate) for most of the time since late April, while Pillar 2 tests have steadily increased (with a few outliers under 50k) to between 80k and 85k in late May, and with a short peak of 118,419 tests on 20 May 2020. One will have to watch, whether there will show up an expected significant effect of the end of the lockdown on the positivity rate (maybe an increase to >2.5%) in the next few days.
The three most important determinants on the number of daily cases by far will be:
- the extent to which the daily lab capacity (Pillar 1 & 2) will further increase
- the extent to which the lab capacity will be utilized: as of 2 June 2020 (date of activity) the lab capacities for Pillar 1 tests have been used by only 60.3% (38,163 out of 63,213 possible tests) and for Pillar 2 tests by 81,7% (94,735 out of 116,000 possible tests)
- whether or not the Pillars 3 & 4 will at some point in time before 30 June 2020 start to produce confirmed cases which will show up in UK's daily report. Short and simple simulation:
one-off increase of positivity rate to a constant 2% as of next day's figures
one-off increase of lab capacity (proportionate for Pillar 1 & 2) by 20% to constant 75,850 (Pillar 1) and 139,200 (Pillar2) per day as of next day's figures
one-off increase of capacity utilization by 20% for Pillar 1-tests to 72.4% and by 10% for Pillar 2-tests to 89.8% as of next day's figures; ceteris paribus
This would leave us with a number of 3,600 new confirmed cases per day, which seems to be reasonable to me as an average over the remaining 27 days left to report until 30 June 2020.
This would add 97,200 new cases to the 279,856 cases already known to result in 377,056 total cases as of 30 June 2020, which is of course a good thing (only undetected infections can carry the spread further...), and which would lie comfortably in the middle of the last but one basket.
However small (or large) the adjustments in the simulation are, I must confess they are unfounded and nothing else but my best guess and some kind of a worst case scenario for the UK. From my gut instinct I suggest the Sit Rep 162 will report about 350k to 355k cases on 30 June 2020, which probably corrects for my errors in the oversimplified simulation from neglecting possible effects from double testing and from Pillars 3 & 4.

Outlook based on an exponential regression of data from Johns Hopkins since 3/21 (start date is arbitrary based on when cases counts became large enough that day-over-day changes stabilized) with a day of week seasonal adjustment. Model indicates 293k cases by end of June.  Naive model does not consider:
1. Increase in testing
2. Reduction in social distancing measures or increased mobility
3. “Herd immunity” estimate While 1 & 2 skew risks towards the upside, I have seen minimal evidence of their impact. These is very little correlation between new tests and new cases in an environment where a large one-off increase in tests is performed (https://www.google.com/amp/s/fivethirtyeight.com/features/coronavirus-case-counts-are-meaningless/amp/). So far, high frequency indicators published in major news publications (restaurant reservations, flights, google/apple mobility) show a massive decline in activity that is curbing the spread. Although the UK gov is expected to release a reopening plan this week, it will likely be slow and will have to combat consumer reticence. The jury is still out on how states and countries with aggressive reopening plans are fairing. In terms of item 3, studies in Germany and New York found that COVID-19 was more widely spread than testing indicated, but still only 25-50% of what is need for herd immunity.  Based on the factors above, I think that the naive model might give a fair representation of what will happen with some buffer between the upper and lower bound of the question and the model output. I think risks are skewed to the upside given uncertainties around the re-opening plan in the UK and case surges due to reopening in other areas. Consumer behavior however could offset these risks.

Following from April 19th rationale, I still think it is judging how low the daily base rate will get through late May-early June that will determine any accuracy on this one. Germany has acted relatively quickly and effectively, and within four weeks daily cases have dropped to approx 30%. The UK has acted less quickly and successfully, and is unlikely to achieve better than halving numbers within 4wks from the peak, more in line with Italy or Spain. It is also troubled by a number of issues: a stressed NHS service, significant lack of PPE, and very low levels of testing.  While daily cases should then continue to decline, this will be partly offset by two things: an increase in testing, and a gradual relaxation of lockdown measures  (Gov. to review 2nd wk of May). Also a perception that we are over the worst could also lead to a slight complacency depending on age/circumstances. The Government will be balancing the easing of restrictions with a clear guide that numbers are substantially lower, but will definitely be under pressure to relax measures in some way before end of May. As a consequence I see the best case scenario, from current total at 140K, as a decline to 3k per day within 2wks, followed by a reduction to under 1K per day within 3 wks, before daily case numbers start to flatten off.

I have gone with a significantly higher set of numbers than the consensus. It feels to me like there are a couple of big picture scenarios to consider. One, we have and keep this under control - effective social distancing and or contact tracing allows Government to essentially control the number of daily cases to keep the NHS from being overwhelmed. We then essentially have a choice about the trade off between the number of cases and the "economic" and other harm people are concerned about. We can either attempt to kill the virus as something spreading in the UK by keeping really strict measures in place - in that case, let's say we have 3k cases per day for the next 10 days, 2k cases per day for the following 10 and then sub 100 for the following 48 - that keeps us in the sub 180k bucket, but if it is even 3.5k for the next 10 days 2,750 for the following 15 and 200 for the remaining 43, that gets us above 180k. Let's say if we did choose to go down that route, we would have 75% chance of staying sub 180k and 25% chance of ending up in the 180-260k bucket. Then let's say we choose to focus more on opening things up. Let's say as above, cases gradually drop to 2k but then we allow them to stay there, that generally gets us in the 180 - 260k cases, but if misjudged a little and end up with 2.5k cases for the last 30 days on average, that gets us in the 260 - 340k bucket and even if we overrun quite a bit but still manage to get the lid back on if things go really wrong, we probably manage to keep within that bucket. However, if we "lose control" and get back on an exponential curve and get uncontrolled spreading, we could easily exceed the 420k cases (and that is probably more likely than the 340 - 420k cases range in that instance). So let's say if we go down that route, we are talking about a 40% chance of ending up in the 180 - 260k bucket (i.e. keeping it under control), 50% a slight misjudgement (260 - 340k) and 10% out of control (420k+). Between the try to crush it and try to have some controlled spread, I think we are probably 25/75. Putting those all together gives me 19% in sub 180k, 36% in 180-260k, 38% in 260-340k and 8% in 420k. Let's say there is also a 5% chance this is a false dawn and it is then going to be a real struggle, so we are 50/50 between 340 - 420k (i.e. things go up but we do get them back under control relatively quickly) and 420k plus (big struggle). HOWEVER, one thing I do not want to miss is that we could well start to see a real increase in testing as part of these containment measures. Let's say cases are currently unreported versus what they will be going forward and moves everything up by a bucket.. Let's say there is a 50% chance that happens. Gives me my final numbers. Overall versus the crowd that has me saying there is more chance of ending up in the 180 - 260k bucket and less of ending up in the 340 - 420k bucket. Overall I am happy with that - I think the 340 - 420k bucket makes relatively little sense as either we have this under control and things will be lower, or we don't and they will be higher

My forecast is significantly different from the crowd.  So I am going to document my thinking and modeling. I am applying a logistic model to fitting to the existing data.  A logistic model is appropriate when the outbreak is slowing down.  There are 2 indicators for that.
1.  The actual daily infected cases has a peak of 8719 on 12 April.  The data are noisy. 
 A broad peak can be see if you do some averaging. 
2.  The Google Mobility reports [1] indicate that the UK lockdown has reached its sustainable impact on 26 March as indicated by the Workplace Mobility.  Past experiences indicate that the outbreak started to slow down about 3 weeks after that.  That means 16 April.  This is consistent with (close to) the 12 April peak in the data. Applying the logistic model indicates 270k infected cases on 30 June.  Of course lots of things could happen before 30 June, especially if there is a long tail in the daily cases.   [1]  [1]  https://www.google.com/covid19/mobility/

With 70 days to go and the WHO giving a 5 day average of 5200 would lead to 488 000  cases, but as stated a fall in new cases is expected over the next two weeks. although it is difficult to know the extent of this drop. If we state that it is 5200 for the next 7 days, then 4500 for 7 days, 4000 for 14 days, 3000 for 14 days, 2000 for 14 days and finally only 1000 new cases a day for the last 14 days. that would give 207 000 cases by the 30th of June. These estimates are based on Italy's declining trend of about 500 fewer new cases per day for each week that pass. This simply proves to show that a high variance in the number of cases is possible, but due to me believing in a fall I will focus on the last estimate rather than the first.

Used Italy's decline in new cases as a model, which peaked about 1 month ago. Increase in Italian new cases over the last month is by a factor of 3.41, multiplying UK cases at the peak by this number puts you on around 252,000 in one month's time from that peak, by May 10/11/12th. UK approach might be more or less effective but that is yet to be determined. 7-day rolling average of change in day-to-day total cases has been erratic but overall has decreased. This metric looks at the % increase or decrease in cases today vs yesterday and those daily changes are update daily for the previous 7 days. I'm using this method for Focus Covid-19 death forecasting group. As seen with total cases in other countries, UK total case increase rate is declining. Over the past week, the number of new cases from one day to the next is about 5% more. Over the next 71 days that rate should fall below 1%. Looking at an average range of  between 1% to 2.5 % yields between 194,000 and 316,000 total cases. With more data, the 7-day average should smooth out, become more linear and will allow the decrease in new case rate to yield an approximate total decrease in rate for this entire time period.

The most pressing issue here is the UK's testing regime and the number of people with mild or no symptoms recovering from Covid-19. Due to the low numbers of tests conducted (~10,000 per day, lab capacity for 100,000 per day) [1], the official numbers do not reflect the actual spread of the virus.  The case numbers could already have reached most of the brackets provided here [3]. Currently, only those with severe symptoms are tested. Those people with mild or no symptoms have not been tested and I guess they won't be tested after they have recovered*. Thus, the forecast is much more concerned with those that show severe conditions than with the actual number of people infected - as capacities (and regulations) do not allow for testing a high number of people with mild symptoms at the moment. The UK government wants to test 100,000 people per day at the beginning of May. They may relax the limitations on who gets tested as a consquence. By then, however, most of the people who did not suffer from severe conditions will have recovered obscuring the actual case numbers. Therefore, the following aspects seem particularly relevant for this forecast: - the reproduction number (Is it getting lower than 1? Or will there be ongoing supply of infected people?) [2]
- recovery rates of infected people with mild or no symptoms (Will there be a smaller pool of people that could potentially be tested?)
- testing capacity (will we see these 100,000 tests per day?)
- the guidelines regulating the testing (are more people eligible to testing?)
- UK government's policy on lockdown and other preventive measures [3] Looking at the numbers, I don't think we'll see a reduction of numbers below 2k per day on average before June (compare to Italy and Spain that still register approximately or more than 3k cases per day). There are ~10 weeks left.  * I may be blindsided by antibody tests here but I know too little about the requirements and capacities needed to perform them in large numbers and I assume they'll receive increased attention as soon as the reproduction number is low enough and priorities shift towards getting back to a more "normal" life. [1] https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2020/04/05/coronavirus-testing-uk-how-many-done/
[2] https://www.cebm.net/covid-19/when-will-it-be-over-an-introduction-to-viral-reproduction-numbers-r0-and-re/
[3] https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/04/08/world/europe/08reuters-health-coronavirus-britain-tracker.html

The decline in numbers tends to be slower than the initial rise, and using cases for Italy and Spain I think we will have a similar decline of the next few weeks. If all goes well we may be under 2,000 per day by then, which would total approx 220K, but not everything will go well. Caveats include: the increasing in testing (we are way behind Italy per capita); lockdown fatigue; relaxing measures too soon due to economic pressures; unrecorded cases such as care homes numbers being included belatedly. Based on this we will comfortably be in the mid-range bin, and perhaps tip above 340K if things go badly wrong.

I am quite confident that the average number of daily confirmed cases won't drop below 2,500 (1 in 10 chance). This is because I think there will be periods of lockdown relaxation prior to the 30th of June as well as (hopefully) much more testing. I also think a 'herd immunity'-esque approach is in the minds of the decision makers, and slowly building up immunity will make sense prior to winter. As long as the rate of new severe cases is within the capacity of the NHS, there will be little energy expended to stop the spread. 15% chance of being more than 420k because 1) the number of confirmed cases doubling >twice in the next 2 months is totally conceivable, 2) if antibody testing is introduced* we'll see lots of retrospectively confirmed cases, 3) I have little faith in people's ability to follow social distancing practices as the economy is restarted (which I think is likely to happen in May). Also, if <99% accurate antibody tests are used widely (and added to confirmed case numbers) there will be an explosion of false positives. I sincerely hope the government/NHS/WHO is incompetent enough to misuse antibody testing but it's worth bearing in mind.

The crux of this question is wide scale testing. In a way we should be asking ourselves “Will the UK implement widespread COVID-19 testing targeting the general population by the 30th June?” - essentially with the aim of identifying previously infected (but now immune) individuals.  The answer to this question directly correlates to the answer we will give here.  As of the 18/4/2020 Spain and Italy are reporting 190,000 and 172,000 cases respectively. My previous forecasts have been accurately based using these countries as base rates.  So will the UK be able to introduce mass testing to identify previously infected / now immune individuals in 73 days time? How would this be achieved, recorded and effected (logistics, infrastructure etc?). What benefit would there be (return to work, identify at risk, prevent second and third rise, herd immunity identification)? What would be the cost vs the benefit - ALARP (as low as reasonably possible).  If the UK were to implement mass testing, I would expect more than 420,000 (~0.6% of the entire population) cases taking into account current, future and past infected individuals.  If not I suspect the rates to be more in line with 260,000 -340,000 cases.  The higher option also includes the scenario of a second rise and breakout of infections following relaxation of lockdown restrictions.  I’d like to hear your thoughts on this one guys.
